column1: Senica (Slovak pronunciation: [ˈsɛɲitsa]; German: Senitz; Hungarian: Szenice) is a town in Trnava Region
column2: western Slovakia. It is located in the north-eastern part of the Záhorie lowland

column1: The name is derived from the word seno ("hay") with the suffix -ica used to form a place name.
Senica's history is closely related with the Branč castle
column2: built in 1251–1261. It was first mentioned in 1256 and received its city privileges in 1396
column3: confirmed in 1463 and 1492. The city was affected by Turkish wars
column4: anti-Habsburg uprisings and reformation and counter-reformations in the 17th century. In 1746
column5: it became seat of a district within the Nitra county.
0.84% Roma and 0.14 Hungarians. The religious makeup was 47.28% Roman Catholics

column1: A significant silk-producing company is based in Senica. The company was established in 1954 under the name ″Slovenský hodváb". In 2005 the production of viscose rayon was halted. After the merger of Slovenský hodváb and Kord to the new company Slovkor
column2: it continued only with the production of Synthetic fiber for technical purposes. In February 2014 the factory chimney
column3: which dominated the city more than half century and was visible from long distance
column5: one of the biggest luminaire companies in East-Central Europe
column6: is also based in Senica. With around 1000 employees and exporting 98% of its production to more than 100 countries
column7: the company is a referent in the economy of Senica.

column1: Senica is one of the locations where Slovak Bandy Association has organised rink bandy sessions. The club is called Športový klub Rytieri Bandy Senica and was founded in 2018.
